item.title: The Xbox Game Pass price hike will convince gamers to switch over to PlayStation and Nintendo
item.itunes:title: The Xbox Game Pass price hike will convince gamers to switch over to PlayStation and Nintendo
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
The Xbox brand is going through a rough patch with everyone after the news of changes coming to their subscription service. The price of Xbox Game Pass Ultimate was increased drastically, which drew the ire of many gamers online, who felt the increase was astronomical and unnecessary. Although Xbox justified the reason for the price increase by showing the amount of games coming to the service and the additional features that Game Pass Ultimate subscribers would have, it wasn't enough to quell the overwhelmingly negative response to the news. And for some who have stuck with the Xbox ecosystem for a long time, it may have been the final straw.

Online threads and forums began flooding with people talking about canceling their Game Pass subscription as a form of protest to the company increasing the price of the service. Things got so bad because of so many people canceling, the web page for the Xbox website to cancel subscriptions started to have errors and become broken. Discussion about Xbox's commitment to gamers who have continuously supported the company was called into question, especially after changing what many considered to be the best deal and value in the industry, and the biggest reason to engage with Xbox as a brand. But with the price change going into effect and the anger from gamers looming online, some people may be jumping ship to other places to get their gaming fix. Here's why the Xbox Game Pass price hike will convince gamers to switch over to PlayStation and Nintendo consoles.

New Game Pass pricing hits hard

Too expensive as a subscription for most

Most subscription services within entertainment end up landing on a similar price point that customers have grown accustomed to. Whether you're watching movies and TV shows on Netflix or HBO Max, or getting a premium subscription to platforms like YouTube, you may end up paying a similar price wherever you go. This was the same thing for Xbox Game Pass Ultimate, which cost gamers around $19.99 through the digital store or at retail. For most people, it was a good sales price for the amount of games you gain access to on Xbox Series X/S or PC. And while other platforms had their own services with access to games digitally through downloads and streaming, Game Pass Ultimate was considered the best value for gamers who wanted access to new games on launch day, as well as a backlog of titles to explore anytime they wanted.

But with the increase in price for Xbox Game Pass Ultimate, that perception has seemingly gone away. It's very hard to justify someone paying $30 every month for a subscription service, especially if it doesn't involve a cellphone or brand-new vehicle in some way. The new price is more than most other streaming services that people often use, with the most expensive currently being Netflix and their 4K premium tier for movies and television shows. Despite Game Pass Ultimate having access to so many games to download to a console, the majority of people will not play most of the 400 titles that the service offers through Game Pass Ultimate, making it even harder to justify the new price. And forcing everyone to pay it is not going to help, especially for those who have been subscribers for a long time already.

Credit: Team Ninja

The announcement from Xbox came with news that in-game rewards for titles from Riot Games and other perks for games like Fortnite would be included, along with unlimited cloud gaming and an assortment of Ubisoft and EA classics. But none of these things are potent enough to convince gamers that the new price is justifiable, or offer enough value to stick with the service throughout the year. Most of the extra perks aren't helpful if someone doesn't play Fortnite, or doesn't play old EA and Ubisoft games. Even with the more than 75 day one releases that are accessible on launch as a subscriber, most of them will not be major titles people would be interested in.

PlayStation Plus looks more appealing now

Greater value over on PSN

The closest comparison to Game Pass would be PlayStation Plus, and more specifically the Premium and Extra tiers of the service. These give subscribers access to an assortment of games from the PlayStation Plus and Classics catalog, which adds more games periodically throughout the year. It's a very similar approach to what Xbox Game Pass did, but with a very different selection of titles that cater more to PlayStation gamers, rather than just the biggest releases. And the price for the highest tier is $17.99 per month, which gives access to everything and looks much more appealing to gamers looking to be smarter with their monthly budget.

The new price change for Xbox Game Pass gives every reason for players to cancel their subscription and switch over to PlayStation Plus. It's not only cheaper, but has enough major games to draw the attention of casual players, even if it doesn't have day one releases. Most of the major games that come out are usually purchased by gamers who were already interested in them, whether they were available through Xbox Game Pass or not. But the benefit that PlayStation has is how many of the major hits for the brand are available in the PS Plus catalog already, offering a pretty substantial list of games someone can get if they just got their console without having to make additional purchases.

Credit: Square Enix

But in addition to that, the Classics Catalog on PlayStation Plus is a wide range of exclusive titles that don't appear anywhere else. If the perks offered with a subscription matter the most for the price you pay, then PlayStation Plus Premium is going to be a smarter option over Xbox Game Pass Ultimate now. There's no real argument to make against someone paying half the price and getting so much more value. It's basically the original way that Game Pass operated, but with an entirely different selection of games.

Switch Online appears even better

A low price for the whole year

Although some may still find Nintendo to be very frugal with their games and services, Nintendo Switch Online also looks better with the Xbox Game Pass changes. For some people, it's hard to jump into the Nintendo ecosystem because third-party games are often better to play elsewhere, despite Nintendo first-party games being as good as they are. But having a Nintendo Switch 2 with Switch Online is the most price-efficient subscription that gamers could get. Paying $49.99 gives access to online multiplayer, the GameChat feature on Switch 2, and the ability to play any of the Nintendo Classics (all platforms) included with the service for the entire year. One payment, for the whole year.

While Switch Online lacks anything involving day one releases, the price point is significantly lower than the other two platforms. And the one-time payment for the Switch Online Expansion gives everything that the service offers for the entire year, which may be more than enough for families who play games together. The entire catalog of classics for Nintendo 64, NES, Super Nintendo, Sega Genesis, GameCube, and Game Boy titles is a very big deal, even if you didn't grow up playing those games on those systems. It's a much better deal than paying $30 every month, even if you never play most of the games that the classics section offers.

Credit: Nintendo

Switching sides after everything

The sad truth is that Xbox is making it harder for Xbox fans to continue supporting them. Gaming is getting more expensive, and people are trying to find different ways to keep engaging with the hobby without paying too much and breaking their bank accounts. Most gamers are convinced that what is being done with Xbox Game Pass is the wrong move for the company, and it's giving everyone reasons to look elsewhere to play games. Die-hard Xbox fans may stay as long as they can, but eventually it'll be harder for them to stick around with Xbox as time goes on. The mass cancellation of subscriptions to Xbox Game Pass should be enough for the company to get the message that gamers are sending them, but it may end up leading to Xbox handing their competition an audience who would've otherwise still supported them without the price hike.

item.title: Steam on Linux: 5 annoying bugs that need to be fixed ASAP
item.itunes:title: Steam on Linux: 5 annoying bugs that need to be fixed ASAP
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
Steam on Linux has come a long way since its early days. Thanks to Proton, it’s now possible to play thousands of Windows games on Linux with just a few clicks. Even so, the overall experience isn’t as polished as it should be. Persistent bugs, display quirks, and a handful of outdated design choices continue to frustrate users.

Valve has done more for Linux gaming than any other company, but these unresolved issues make Steam feel unfinished.

These aren’t minor inconveniences. Some of these issues make Steam feel unreliable, and others make it seem disconnected from how modern Linux systems work. If Valve wants Steam to feel like a premium experience on Linux, these long-standing issues need genuine attention.

Steam disables your screensaver and never turns it back on

A long-standing bug that messes with power management

One of the most frustrating issues with Steam on Linux is its interference with screensavers and power management settings for displays. When you start Steam or launch a game, it disables your screensaver and display sleep features, which makes sense during gameplay. The problem is that it rarely restores those settings afterward. Once you close the client, your screensaver stays disabled until you log out or restart your computer. That’s not how a well-behaved desktop app should work.

I’ve tried numerous fixes for this issue, including the addition of a command-line parameter that should prevent Steam from ever touching screensaver settings. None has proven a consistent fix for the issue.

Reports about this issue have circulated for years in Valve’s GitHub tracker. Steam uses power inhibition to prevent screens from dimming during gameplay, but it sometimes leaves this inhibition active even when the game is idle. The Arch Linux wiki even notes this, stating that Steam disables screensavers regardless of whether a game is running. Some users launch Steam with SDL_VIDEO_ALLOW_SCREENSAVER=1 or use D-Bus commands to release inhibitor locks, but those are temporary fixes. The client should be smart enough to handle that automatically.

This problem might seem minor, but it’s not. It can keep your monitor awake for hours, waste energy, and shorten the display lifespan. Valve could easily fix this by refining its session logic to only inhibit screen sleep when necessary and always reset those settings when a session ends. That kind of polish is exactly what Linux users expect from a platform leader.

Scaling and DPI support are still a mess

Steam ignores or mishandles display scaling under Linux

Steam’s scaling behavior is one of the most obvious signs that it still doesn’t feel native on Linux. On high-resolution or multi-monitor setups, text and icons often appear too small or stretched. The client’s own “Scale text and icons to match monitor settings” option rarely works under Wayland, and in some cases, it does nothing at all. For users with fractional scaling enabled, Steam’s interface may appear uneven and difficult to read.

Some of the worst cases appear when Steam runs under XWayland. The window may render at a low internal resolution and then be upscaled by the compositor, resulting in everything appearing blurry. You can work around it by running Steam through Gamescope or adjusting compositor settings, but those solutions are far from convenient. They also shouldn’t be necessary in a modern desktop environment. Valve’s other projects, such as the Steam Deck, demonstrate that it knows how to handle scaling correctly.

Fixing this would bring a huge improvement in usability. The Steam client should read system-level scaling values and adapt in real time, just like native Linux apps do. With so many distributions now defaulting to Wayland and high-DPI displays becoming the standard, proper scaling is no longer optional. It’s a requirement for a clean and consistent experience.

The blank client window problem won’t die

Steam sometimes launches to a completely empty screen

Another issue that’s been plaguing users for years is the infamous blank Steam window. You launch the client, log in, and instead of seeing your library or store, you get an empty gray or black screen. It’s one of those bugs that seem random but show up frequently enough to be considered persistent. Sometimes restarting the client works, and other times the only way to fix it is by launching Big Picture mode.

This problem has been linked to several different causes. On Wayland, GPU handoff issues and compositor quirks can prevent Steam’s Chromium-based interface from drawing correctly. On dual-GPU systems, Steam sometimes opens using the wrong GPU and fails to render altogether. Even on X11 systems, the same blank window can appear after updates or runtime changes. The fact that it’s survived so many UI revisions suggests a deeper architectural flaw.

Users shouldn’t have to troubleshoot their game launcher just to play games. Valve needs to make Steam’s graphical initialization more reliable and resilient to differences between drivers and compositors. When the client fails to load its own interface, it undermines user confidence and makes Linux gaming feel unstable. This should be one of the first things Valve addresses.

Proton still needs consistency improvements

Compatibility issues keep some games from launching properly

Proton has revolutionized Linux gaming by making Windows titles playable with minimal effort. It works impressively well most of the time, but when it doesn’t, the experience quickly becomes frustrating. Some games fail to launch at all, while others crash or stutter so badly they’re unplayable. The inconsistency makes it difficult for users to know what to expect from one title to the next.

Many players end up experimenting with different Proton versions or tweaking launch options to find a working combination. Others have had to reinstall the Steam runtime entirely just to fix missing dependencies. These issues often stem from how Steam manages compatibility layers and runtime libraries. When things break, there’s rarely any feedback to help users understand what went wrong.

Valve could make Proton far more dependable by integrating better error reporting and automatic troubleshooting. If the client could detect common dependency conflicts or runtime mismatches, it could automatically switch to a different version or apply patches. A more predictable Proton experience would reduce frustration and make gaming on Linux feel as smooth as it does on Windows.

Wayland and GPU support remain unreliable

Poor integration with modern Linux desktop environments

Wayland has become the default display server on most major Linux distributions, but Steam still struggles with it. Users report flickering windows, blank screens, and missing UI elements when running the client or launching games. Dual-GPU systems often confuse Steam, which may render on the wrong card or cause the system to crash entirely. This issue occurs most frequently due to a configuration entry called PrefersNonDefaultGPU=true, which can cause Steam to select the incorrect GPU.

Steam’s window scaling on Wayland also remains unreliable. On high-DPI setups, the interface often appears at half resolution and is then upscaled, resulting in blurry text and misaligned menus. Some compositors let users disable XWayland scaling to work around the problem, but that’s an unnecessary complication. Valve already solved these challenges on the Steam Deck, which uses a Wayland-based compositor with Gamescope.

Applying those same fixes to the desktop client would show that Valve is serious about Linux beyond the Steam Deck. Better GPU detection, proper Wayland support, and more consistent rendering would eliminate some of the most frustrating user experiences. The Linux desktop has matured quickly, and Steam needs to keep up if Valve wants to maintain its leadership in the space.

Why Valve needs to address these problems now

Valve has done more for Linux gaming than any other company, but these unresolved issues make Steam feel unfinished. Problems such as the screensaver lockout and blank client windows hinder usability. Inconsistent Proton behavior and weak Wayland integration frustrate both newcomers and long-time Linux users alike.

Valve already solved these challenges on the Steam Deck, which uses a Wayland-based compositor with Gamescope.

Fixing these bugs wouldn’t just make Steam more stable; it would also improve the overall experience. It would show that Valve sees Linux as a platform worthy of the same level of polish as Windows or the Steam Deck. The necessary tools and community support are already in place. All that’s missing is the attention to detail that turns a functional client into a great one.

Steam

Steam has done wonders for Linux gaming, but there's still so much that could be better.

Proton has revolutionized Linux gaming by making Windows titles playable with minimal effort. It works impressively well most of the time, but when it doesn’t, the experience quickly becomes frustrating. Some games fail to launch at all, while others crash or stutter so badly they’re unplayable. The inconsistency makes it difficult for users to know what to expect from one title to the next.

Many players end up experimenting with different Proton versions or tweaking launch options to find a working combination. Others have had to reinstall the Steam runtime entirely just to fix missing dependencies. These issues often stem from how Steam manages compatibility layers and runtime libraries. When things break, there’s rarely any feedback to help users understand what went wrong.

Valve could make Proton far more dependable by integrating better error reporting and automatic troubleshooting. If the client could detect common dependency conflicts or runtime mismatches, it could automatically switch to a different version or apply patches. A more predictable Proton experience would reduce frustration and make gaming on Linux feel as smooth as it does on Windows.

Wayland and GPU support remain unreliable

Poor integration with modern Linux desktop environments

Wayland has become the default display server on most major Linux distributions, but Steam still struggles with it. Users report flickering windows, blank screens, and missing UI elements when running the client or launching games. Dual-GPU systems often confuse Steam, which may render on the wrong card or cause the system to crash entirely. This issue occurs most frequently due to a configuration entry called PrefersNonDefaultGPU=true, which can cause Steam to select the incorrect GPU.

Steam’s window scaling on Wayland also remains unreliable. On high-DPI setups, the interface often appears at half resolution and is then upscaled, resulting in blurry text and misaligned menus. Some compositors let users disable XWayland scaling to work around the problem, but that’s an unnecessary complication. Valve already solved these challenges on the Steam Deck, which uses a Wayland-based compositor with Gamescope.

Applying those same fixes to the desktop client would show that Valve is serious about Linux beyond the Steam Deck. Better GPU detection, proper Wayland support, and more consistent rendering would eliminate some of the most frustrating user experiences. The Linux desktop has matured quickly, and Steam needs to keep up if Valve wants to maintain its leadership in the space.

Why Valve needs to address these problems now

Valve has done more for Linux gaming than any other company, but these unresolved issues make Steam feel unfinished. Problems such as the screensaver lockout and blank client windows hinder usability. Inconsistent Proton behavior and weak Wayland integration frustrate both newcomers and long-time Linux users alike.

Valve already solved these challenges on the Steam Deck, which uses a Wayland-based compositor with Gamescope.

Fixing these bugs wouldn’t just make Steam more stable; it would also improve the overall experience. It would show that Valve sees Linux as a platform worthy of the same level of polish as Windows or the Steam Deck. The necessary tools and community support are already in place. All that’s missing is the attention to detail that turns a functional client into a great one.
